tossups.question: This artist won an early intellectual property lawsuit after suing the Dal Jesus family and Marcantonio Raimondi. Shortly after his apprenticeship to Michael Wolgemut ("MISH-ah-el VOL-guh-moot"), this artist painted himself holding a thistle. This artist clutches a fur coat in another self-portrait in which he painted himself “with indelible colors at the age of (*) 28 years.” This artist stares directly at the viewer in that self-portrait in a pose reminiscent of other artists’ Salvator Mundi. A gourd hangs from the rafters and a skull sits on the windowsill in a work by this artist whose foreground depicts a sleeping dog and a lion. For 10 points, name this German artist who depicted the translation of the Vulgate in his engraving St. Jerome in his Study.
tossups.answer: Albrecht Dürer

tossups.question: Luce Irigaray (“LOOSE ee-ree-gah-RAY”) was expelled from a Paris school named for this man for her thesis Speculum of the Other Woman. J. M. Masson argued that this thinker suppressed theories about child abuse in the controversial book The Assault on Truth. This man’s views that one group of people were “a strange, inferior, less-than-human species” are attacked in a 1963 book by Betty Friedan. (*) Karen Horney (“HORN-eye”) broke from a theory proposed by this man by arguing that men were drawn to creative endeavors as a compensation for not being able to procreate. This man described how one concept led to girls disparaging their mothers for appearing to be castrated. For 10 points, name this man who proposed the theory of penis envy and founded psychoanalysis.
tossups.answer: Sigmund Freud [or Sigismund Schlomo Freud]

tossups.question: A square matrix has this property if and only if its characteristic polynomial has a nonzero constant term. An n-by-n matrix also has this property if it has n pivot points. Alternatively, a square matrix over the complex numbers has this property if all of its eigenvalues are non-zero. Square matrices are called non-singular if they have this property, which is true if and only if they have a non-zero (*) determinant. A function f-of-x has this property if there is another function g-of-x such that (read slowly) f-of-g-of-x and g-of-f-of-x both equal x. Therefore, functions that are not bijective and therefore fail to be injective or surjective, such as the parabola x-squared, do not have this property. For 10 points, name this property that intuitively allows you to “undo” a function.
tossups.answer: invertible [or invertibility; accept descriptions such as having an inverse; prompt on injectivity or injective or one-to-one before “non-singular” is read; prompt on non-zero determinant before mentioned]

tossups.question: This character repeats the word “kill” six times after calling life a “great stage of fools.” This character says his heart “shall break into a hundred thousand flaws” and that “man’s life’s as cheap as beast’s” in a speech that begins “O, reason not the need.” This character tells “cataracts and hurricanoes” to “rumble thy bellyful” in a speech in which he cries out, (*) “blow, winds, and crack your cheeks!” This character calls himself “more sinn’d against than sinning” during a storm that Kent rescues him from. While holding the corpse of his daughter, this man exclaims “never, never, never, never, never” before dying. Regan, Goneril, and Cordelia are the daughters of, for 10 points, what Shakespearean king?
tossups.answer: King Lear

tossups.question: Inhibition of the FOXN1 gene results in a lack of these cells, which can be seen in a strain of hairless lab mice. Cells called mTECs prevent harmful examples of these cells from developing. These cells are artificially “programmed” in CAR (“car”) therapy. Before maturing, these cells are known as double-negative before they develop their receptors, then become double-positive. Like NK cells, a class of these cells contains granules of perforin and granzyme. These cells are classified by whether they express (*) CD4 or CD8. These MHC-recognizing cells develop from thymocytes and come in cytotoxic and helper varieties. For 10 points, name this class of lymphocytes that help mediate adaptive immunity with B cells.
tossups.answer: T cells [accept cytotoxic T cells or helper T cells or killer T cells; prompt on leukocytes or white blood cells]

tossups.question: In 2001, this company paid 18 million dollars to Jonathan Tasini and others in a dispute over database rights. This company was a party alongside Ralph Abernathy in a lawsuit over the ad “Heed Their Rising Voices.” In an opinion in a lawsuit by Bill Cosby, Clarence Thomas argued against the “actual malice” libel standard that was established by a case named for this company. This company has long been controlled by the Sulzberger family. A city commissioner from (*) Montgomery, Alabama, was awarded five hundred thousand dollars in a lawsuit against this company in a decision overturned in the Sullivan case. In 2020, this company controversially allowed Tom Cotton to publish the “Send in the Troops” editorial. For 10 points, name this American “newspaper of record.”
tossups.answer: New York Times [or The New York Times Company; prompt on The Times Company]

tossups.question: Tourists and other people engaged in this activity in Waitomo, New Zealand, often take selfies in front of blue glowworms. Several people have died partaking in this activity in France in a location named for Joseph Berger following heavy rainfall. Howard and Deb Limbert helped popularize this activity in places like Hang Sơn Đoòng (“hahng sun dong”), nicknamed the “Great Wall of Vietnam.” In 2018, a soccer team that engaged in this activity was (*) stranded in Tham Luang Nang Non, Thailand. This activity is the recreational equivalent of speleology. The largest venue for people engaged in this activity in the US is in a “Mammoth” system in Kentucky. For 10 points, name this activity where one might explore regions filled with stalactites.
tossups.answer: caving [or spelunking; or cave diving; or exploring caves; or touring caves; or potholing; accept speleology before mentioned; prompt on sight-seeing or exploring or scuba diving by asking “in what locations?”]

tossups.question: Samuel Rickless distinguished two theories of these concepts as the “Whole Pie Model” and the “Piece-of-Pie Model,” which are both shown to be inconsistent. Another criticism of these entities, which uses the property that they cannot partake of themselves to create an infinite regress, is called the “Third (*) Man Argument.” The Sun is used as an analogy for one of these concepts corresponding to “the Good.” The difference between shadows and the real world is an analogy for the difference between the real world and the world of these entities in the Allegory of the Cave. For 10 points, name these Ideal entities that exist in their own non-physical world, according to Plato.
tossups.answer: forms [or eidoi; accept ideas before “Ideal” is read, but prompt after; accept Form of the Good]

tossups.question: A girl who is “wild to do something for Father” cries over the loss of this stuff in a chapter that opens with an ominous telegram from Civil War-era Washington, D.C. This stuff titles a short story about a girl from Eau Claire, Wisconsin, who initially bores her sophisticated cousin Marjorie. Proceeds from selling this stuff allow Marmee to visit her sick husband in Little Women; that stuff of this type was described as Jo’s “one beauty.” In an (*) F. Scott Fitzgerald short story, removing most of this stuff finally makes Bernice more like a flapper. In another story, Della sells this stuff so she can buy a Christmas present for Jim. For 10 points, Jim sells his watch in “The Gift of the Magi” to buy a comb for Della to comb what stuff on her head?
tossups.answer: hair [accept “Bernice Bobs Her Hair”]

tossups.question: One side in this larger war had to divert troops following the Bloody Diet at Onod to quell Ferenc Rakoczi’s (“FEH-rents RAH-ko-tsee’s”) quest for an independent Hungary. After the destruction of a treasure fleet at the Battle of Vigo Bay during this conflict, Pedro the Pacific signed the Methuen (“muh-THOO-in”) Treaty that established a wine trade with England. An army in this war supporting future Holy Roman Emperor Charles VI (“the sixth”) won a Pyrrhic victory under Eugene of Savoy at (*) Malplaquet. This war began when Philippe, Duc d’Anjou was announced as the candidate for kingship by Louis XIV (“the fourteenth”). The British seizure of Gibraltar was ratified in the Treaty of Utrecht that ended this conflict. For 10 points, name this 1701 to 1714 conflict for control of an empire with capital at Madrid.
tossups.answer: War of Spanish Succession [or Queen Anne’s War; prompt on Rákóczi’s War of Independence or the Hungarian War of Independence until “Hungary” is read by asking “in what war was Austria also fighting during this time?”]

tossups.question: Some sources argue that the ashrama named after these places, the second of four ashramas, is praiseworthy because it performs sacrifices and sustains other ashramas. In Tamil Nadu, these places are often demarcated from surrounding space by a rice flour drawing called a kolam. Hindus often perform the griha pravesh ritual to inaugurate entering into one of these places for the first time. In Buddhism, laypeople are often referred to as (*) “holders” of these places in contrast to monastics who renounce worldly possessions. Hindus who have Western-built examples of these places might create dedicated altars from closet spaces. For 10 points, name these buildings where daily pujas might be performed in a special room away from the bedroom.
tossups.answer: homes [or houses; accept ghar before “griha” is read; accept householders or homeowners]

tossups.question: This quantity for a given object is measured in units of power by a device that uses its moving mode to self-calibrate. The known values of the cesium standard and speed of light allow this quantity’s unit to be defined by fixing the value of Planck’s constant. Changes in this quantity due to a magnetic field were related to a material’s susceptibility by Louis Gouy (“lwee gwee”). Bryan (*) Kibble designed a device for precisely measuring this quantity. One attempt to define this quantity’s unit involved the creation of a perfect silicon ball, which also allows the determination of Avogadro’s number. In 2019, this quantity was unpinned from the physical platinum-iridium cylinder previously used to define its unit. For 10 points, name this quantity found with a balance and measured in kilograms.
tossups.answer: mass [or weight; prompt on gravitational force; do not accept or prompt on “gravity”]

tossups.question: One section of this collection opens with repeated flute flourishes before the strings enter playing an E minor scale up to B, then B, C, C, B. This collection, which opens with a harp playing a recurring motif of B-flat, E-flat, D, B-flat, adapted a theme from Giuseppe Cenci’s (“CHEN-chee’s”) song “La Mantovana” for its second section, also the basis for “Hatikvah,” Israel’s national anthem. The war hymn “Ye Who Are Warriors of God” is quoted in this collection’s fifth section, which depicts the (*) Hussite city of Tábor. This collection opens by depicting the “High Castle” Vyšehrad (“VISH-eh-raht”) and uses tone painting with woodwinds to depict the swirling St. John’s Rapids in its “Vltava” (“vul-TAH-vah”) movement. For 10 points, name this nationalistic tone poem by Bedřich Smetana (“BED-reekh SMEH-tah-nah”)?
tossups.answer: Má vlast [or My Country or My Homeland; prompt on “Vyšehrad” or “Vltava” or “Die Moldau” or “Tábor” by asking “what larger work is that piece a part of?”]

tossups.question: The founder of this city built a palace whose 120-foot green dome had a horseman whose lance was supposedly able to rotate in the direction of his enemies. A pair of brothers working in this city in the 9th century dreamed up a primitive version of a gas mask in their The Book of Ingenious Devices. Construction on this “Round City” was supervised by the Barmakid family. The end of a Golden Age is usually dated to the 1258 (*) sack of this “Dome of Peace” by Hulagu Khan. A ruler of this city once sent a water clock to Charlemagne and may have founded the House of Wisdom. This city was built as a more secure capital for Al-Mansur, the leader of the Abbasid Caliphate. For 10 points, name this city on the Tigris River, the capital of Iraq.
tossups.answer: Baghdad

tossups.question: This molecule forms bright blue compounds from phenols like salicylate (“suh-LISS-ill-ate”) in the presence of hypochlorite, which also chlorinates this molecule in the first step of the Olin Raschig process. Tetraiodomercurate (“tetra-iodo-mercu-rate”) reacts with this molecule to produce a yellow color in colorimetric assays using Nessler’s reagent. This is the lightest molecule to undergo a pyramidal inversion. Two units of this molecule are needed to form a single (*) hydrazine. Bleach reacts with this compound to produce the toxic chloramines that give pools their smell; on its own, it has a strong and distinct smell. The synthesis of this weak base requires tremendous energy to break the triple bond of nitrogen gas. For 10 points, name this molecule whose formula is NH3.
tossups.answer: ammonia [accept NH3 before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on “ammonium”]

tossups.question: A mythological man of this name selected 12 men to administer the law after choosing the site of the town Sigtun. That man of this name divided Saxland among his three sons before journeying on to Reidgotaland, and had a gift of prophecy that prompted him to leave Turkey. A god of this name won a race on which he had wagered his head against Hrungnir. That god of this name used a ring from (*) Andvari’s treasure trove to cover a dead creature’s whisker, thus repaying Otter’s ransom. Atop this god’s hall stands a goat whose udders produce mead for the Einherjar (“ANE-her-yahr”). In exchange for a drink from the Well of Mimir, he sacrificed one of his body parts. At Ragnarok, this god will fall in battle against Fenrir. For 10 points, name this Norse All-Father.
tossups.answer: Odin [or Woden or Voden]

tossups.question: An Act IV aria by this composer that directly leads into an “Ave Maria” features a soprano repeating the word “salce” (“SAHL­-chay”) while reminiscing about a mournful folk ballad. The title character sings about “the Muslim’s pride” in the aria “Esultate” (“eh-sool-TAH-tay”) in the stormy opening of that Shakespeare-inspired opera by this composer, who also wrote an opera based on Alexandre Dumas’s novel The Lady with the (*) Camellias. The title character of an opera by this composer sings the aria “Sempre libera” (“SEM-pray LEE-beh-ra”) while a man sings about love in the distance. In that opera by this composer, Alfredo throws his casino winnings at the feet of Violetta Valéry, who later dies of tuberculosis. For 10 points, name this Italian composer of Otello and La traviata.
tossups.answer: Giuseppe Verdi [or Giuseppe Fortunino Francesco Verdi]

tossups.question: The narrator of this book is visited by Emmanuelson, an actor who wishes to perform a scene from Henrik Ibsen’s Ghosts. Sydney Pollack directed an Oscar-winning film adaptation of this book, whose narrator adjudicates over a shooting accident where one of her “squatters” is injured in its second section. This memoir, which includes a section titled “Notes From an Immigrant’s Handbook,” was followed by the book (*) Shadows on the Grass. The protagonist flies in a “moth machine” airplane owned by the hunter Denys Finch-Hatton in this memoir by the author of “Babette’s Feast,” and it ends with the author leaving her coffee plantation in the Ngong Hills. For 10 points, name this memoir set in Kenya by Danish author Isak Dinesen.
tossups.answer: Out of Africa

tossups.question: During World War II, Bell Labs’ Calvin Souther Fuller helped create the GRS alternative to this critical good. Thomas Hancock invented the masticator for recycling this good and possibly a method for hardening it. Léon Rom’s organization for enforcing quotas in harvesting this good made heavy use of the chicotte (“shee-CUT”), a whip made from twisted hippo hide. A missionary named William Sheppard claimed that he had seen 81 (*) hands burning in a bonfire severed from “uncooperative” harvesters of this resource by the Force Publique. Henry Ford established a Brazilian city in a bid to secure this resource for his cars. This good was widely tapped from trees in the Belgian Congo. For 10 points, name this good necessary for making tires.
tossups.answer: rubber [or natural rubber; or vulcanized rubber; or artificial rubber; or latex; or India rubber; or Amazonian rubber]

tossups.question: A poetic reformer who wrote in this language adopted a word for “cuckoo” as his pen name when he began coughing up blood because of tuberculosis. The instruction to climb a mountain, “but slowly, slowly!,” is given to a snail in a poem in this language by Issa. Critical insight follows each of thirty pairs of poems in this language in an anthology titled for a game in which children compare two seashells. The first stanza of a (*) collaborative form in this language became its own poetic form, in which two images are juxtaposed and separated by a “cutting word.” A poem in that genre from this language evokes springtime through the splash made by a frog jumping into a pond. For 10 points, name this language in which Shiki and Basho wrote haiku.
tossups.answer: Japanese [or Nihongo]

tossups.question: Historian Phillip Thomas Tucker records how, during this battle, a “sharpshooting female patriot” killed an enemy officer on King Street. Carl von Donop stranded this battle’s losing side after a skirmish at Mount Holly. Troops stationed at McConkey’s Ferry were the only division of the winning side to show up to this battle, unlike those under the command of John Cadwalader and James Ewing. A commander at this battle, (*) Johann Rall, was not actually drunk from holiday festivities. Some 900 men were captured in this battle after commanders like Nathanael Greene made a nighttime crossing of the Delaware River. For 10 points, name this Revolutionary War victory for George Washington in New Jersey.
tossups.answer: Battle of Trenton

bonuses.leadin: Inexact differentials have this property and thus cannot be expressed as a function of state variables. For 10 points each:
answers: path dependence [or path dependent; do not accept or prompt on “path independence”]
work [accept PV work]
temperature [or T; accept isotherms, isothermal surface, or isothermal processes]
parts: Name this property. In the first law of thermodynamics, adding two terms with this property yields one without it.

This inexact differential is expressed as PdV and has a negative sign because it follows the convention of the system acting on the surroundings, not vice versa. The change in internal energy equals this quantity plus heat.

An adiabatic process produces only work and moves between two curves that are constant in this quantity. When this quantity is constant, work is proportional to the natural log of the ratio of final to initial volume.

bonuses.leadin: Some older manuscripts of this book end abruptly with three women “saying nothing to anyone, for they were afraid.” For 10 points each:
answers: Gospel of Mark
Desiderius Erasmus [or Desiderius Erasmus Roterodamus; or Erasmus of Rotterdam]
King James Version [or KJV; or King James Bible or KJB; or Authorized King James Version or AKJV]
parts: Name this book whose last twelve verses, or “Longer Ending,” are subject to academic debate about their authenticity. In those verses of this book, the apostles are given the Great Commission to proclaim the gospel to all nations.
Mark’s Longer Ending was found in all Greek manuscripts available to this humanist scholar, who compiled Greek New Testament manuscripts into the Textus Receptus.
The Textus Receptus is the basis for this Bible translation, which was commissioned by its namesake king of England.

bonuses.leadin: In 2019, the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston acquired a study for this painting that omits one of the title figures. For 10 points each:
answers: The Women of Algiers in Their Apartment [or Femmes d’Alger dans leur appartement]
Eugene Delacroix (“duh-lah-KWAH”) [or Ferdinand Victor Eugene Delacroix]
Pierre-Auguste Renoir
parts: Identify this painting, sketches of which were made during the artist’s 1832 trip abroad with Count Charles-Edgar de Mornay. A figure in this painting holds the end of a hookah.
This artist painted numerous orientalist works like The Women of Algiers and The Massacre at Chios. He is most famous for painting Liberty Leading the People.

This later artist imagined three Parisian women “Dressed in Algerian costumes.” In another of his paintings, Gustave Caillebotte (“kye-BUT”) wears a straw hat as he dines with others at the Maison Fournaise (“may-ZAWN foor-NEZ”) restaurant on the Seine (“sen”).

bonuses.leadin: This temple was legendarily founded by an Indian monk named Batuo in 495 CE. For 10 points each:
answers: Shaolin Temple [or Shaolin Monastery]
Red Turban Rebellion [or Hóngjīn Qǐyì; prompt on the fall of the Yuan dynasty or the rise of the Ming dynasty or equivalents]
Shanghai [or Huátíng; or Shēnchéng; or HùVu]
parts: Identify this temple on the slope of Mount Song in Henan (“huh-nahn”) Province where a monk named Bodhidharma helped develop China’s martial arts tradition.

Much of the Shaolin Temple was destroyed in the 14th century during this Chinese rebellion, whose leader claimed to be a reincarnation of Maitreya. Korea under the Goryeo (“kor-yuh”) dynasty was invaded during this rebellion.
The Stupa of the Four Heroic Monks in this city honors Shaolin monks who died at the Battle of Taozhai (“tao-jye”) in 1555. Today, this financial capital of China is the country’s most populous city.

bonuses.leadin: The author of this “modern tragedy” wrote an alternate ending to please German censors that he later called a “barbaric act of violence” to the play. For 10 points each:
answers: A Doll’s House [or Et dukkehjem]
Henrik Ibsen
closet dramas
parts: Name this play whose controversial original ending was explored in a modern sequel by Lucas Hnath (“nayth”). Nils Krogstad blackmails the central character in this play.
A Doll’s House is by this Norwegian playwright of The Wild Duck.

Ibsen’s Peer Gynt is a play described by this adjective, meaning it was primarily meant to be read instead of performed. Catherine Burroughs’s book on these dramas argues they’re “dominated by a ‘literary’… element conducive to the act of contemplation.”

bonuses.leadin: A thought experiment named for this man concerns the monetary distributions D1 and D2. For 10 points each:
answers: Wilt Chamberlain [or Wilton Norman Chamberlain]
Robert Nozick
libertarianism
parts: Name this person who receives 25 cents from one million people in that thought experiment. Since everyone consented to distribution D2, the author argues that D2 is just.
This philosopher created that “paying Wilt Chamberlain” thought experiment while advocating a “night watchman state” in his book Anarchy, State, and Utopia.
Nozick pushed a right-wing version of this philosophy in Anarchy, State, and Utopia. Partisans of this viewpoint support drastically reducing intervention by the state.

bonuses.leadin: The plaintiff in this case went on to work at the Mayo Clinic where he later treated the justice who wrote the majority opinion in it, Lewis Powell. For 10 points each:
answers: Regents v. Bakke [or Regents of the Univ. of Cal. v. Bakke; prompt on Regents]
Grutter v. Bollinger [or Barbara Grutter, Petitioner v. Lee Bollinger, et al.]
Richard Nixon [or Richard Milhous Nixon]
parts: Name this 1978 Supreme Court case about race-based admission quotas at a California medical school.

Generals such as John Shalikashvili (“shah-lee-ka-SHVEE-lee”) joined the “military brief” that was influential in deciding this later affirmative action case. This case was decided on the same day as a similar case named for Gratz.

This president promoted affirmative action in federal contracts through the Philadelphia Order. The dog-whistle politics of his “Southern Strategy” helped him secure states like Florida in the 1968 election.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about non-Newtonian fluids that are edible, mostly.
answers: elastic [or elasticity; accept elastic effects]
stress [accept yield stress; accept shear stress]
thixotropy [or thixotropic fluid]
parts: Whipped cream exhibits tastiness, viscous effects, and effects described by this word. Unlike plastic materials, these materials return to their original shape and size after being deformed.
Toothpaste caves under high values of this quantity because it’s a Bingham plastic. Young’s modulus is the ratio of this quantity to strain.

Peanut butter, especially when mixed with jelly, displays this behavior, just like ketchup. In this common behavior, applying shear stress to a colloidal suspension causes it to have a lower viscosity; in other words, shaking ketchup makes it thinner.

bonuses.leadin: An author born in this modern country coined the proverb “A rolling stone gathers no moss” in his Sententiae. For 10 points each:
answers: Syria [or Syrian Arab Republic] (The contemporary poet is Adunis.)
Seneca the Younger [or Lucius Annaeus Seneca]
Ovid [or Naso; or Publius Ovidius Naso]
parts: Name this country that the aforementioned member of the gens Publilius was named after. This modern country was the birthplace of a contemporary author with the pen name Adunis who wrote Songs of Mihyar.
Publilius Syrus’s fans include this Roman philosopher, who quoted him in two of the Moral Letters to Lucilius. This philosopher also wrote the bloody tragedies Thyestes and Hercules Furens.
The pen name of Syrian poet Adunis (“ah-doh-NEESE”) reflects his “pan-Mediterranean muses,” such as this poet whose tale of Venus and Adonis is included in Adunis’s translation of his Metamorphoses.

bonuses.leadin: Several of Niccolò Paganini’s 24 Caprices require the violinist to play portato, or with slurred notes each articulated in this manner. For 10 points each:
answers: staccato
arpeggios [or arpeggi; accept “The Arpeggio”]
ricochet bowing [or jeté; accept saltando, sautillé, or spiccato due to conflation]
parts: Name this style of articulation, usually performed by shortening notes to sound disconnected. This articulation is contrasted with playing legato.
The first of Paganini’s caprices is nicknamed for one of these “broken chords,” in which the notes of a chord are played in series rather than simultaneously.
This bowing creates a series of notes that split the two halves of Paganini’s caprice “La Chasse (“shahss”).” The violinist “throws” the bow onto the strings so that it bounces in this technique.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about comedians who have moved into politics.
answers: Ukraine [or the Ukraine]
Five Star Movement [or Five Stars Movement; or Movimento 5 Stelle; or M5S]
Iceland [or Ísland] (The comedian was Jón Gnarr, born Jón Gunnar Kristinsson.)
parts: Volodymyr Zelenskiy, who played a history teacher-turned-president on television, became the real-life president of this country in 2019 and quickly faced some pressure to investigate Hunter Biden.
This Italian political party was co-founded by TV actor Beppe Grillo and asserts that access to the Internet is a fundamental right.

A comedian was elected mayor of this country’s capital after the 2008 financial crisis and spent years battling its restrictive naming committee. This country sentenced Kaupthing Bank executives to prison after the financial crisis.

bonuses.leadin: Selmer Bringsjord originated a creativity test based on this thinker’s musings that machines could not produce original work. For 10 points each:
answers: Ada Lovelace [or Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace; or Ada Byron; accept Ada]
Alan Turing [or Alan Mathison Turing; accept Turing test or Turing machines]
Stephen Wolfram [accept Wolfram Language]
parts: Identify this computer scientist who names a language derived from Pascal and an award given by the Association for Women in Computing.
The various Lovelace tests are extensions on the imitation game named for this man, which has supposedly been passed by various AI. His namesake machines can compute any algorithm.

This later computer scientist defended Lovelace from charges that her contributions to the field have been overhyped. This man’s namesake programming language powers a computing system called Mathematica.

bonuses.leadin: The early rulers of these people, including Asparukh, are listed in the Nominalia. For 10 points each:
answers: Bulgars [or Bulgarians]
Constantinople [or Byzantium; prompt on Istanbul]
Boris I [or Boris-Mihail; or Boris Michael; or Boris Fyodorovich Godunov]
parts: Name these people who were soundly defeated at the Battle of Kleidion by Basil II, who was nicknamed the “Slayer” of these people.
The Bulgars were a frequent enemy of the Byzantine Empire, though the two fought together from 717 to 718 to repel a Umayyad invasion against this capital city of the Byzantines.

The Bulgars converted to Christianity under a king of this name, who ended his abdication after his son Vladimir reverted to paganism. A Russian ruler of this first name issued the Edict of 1587 formally bonding serfs to the land.

bonuses.leadin: A character named Jason 1 curses Nate Silver in a scene from Matthew Lopez’s lengthy stage adaptation of this novel, The Inheritance. For 10 points each:
answers: Howards End
E. M. Forster [or Edward Morgan Forster]
Leonard Bast [or Leonard Bast]
parts: Name this 1910 novel that also loosely inspired Zadie Smith’s novel On Beauty. The protagonist of Smith’s novel shares his name with the country house that titles this novel, in which the Schlegel sisters appear.
Lopez makes this author of Howards End and A Passage to India a character named Morgan in The Inheritance.

In The Inheritance, this character from Howards End is partly represented by the social climber Adam McDowell. In the original novel, this character dies of a heart attack after being beaten with a saber by Charles Wilcox.

bonuses.leadin: In the 17th century, Anne Marie Orsini introduced the practice of perfuming these objects with neroli oil. For 10 points each:
answers: gloves [or lady’s gloves; or mittens; accept opera gloves]
commedia dell’arte [or Italian comedy; or Comédie-Italienne]
Cologne [or Koln; accept eau de cologne]
parts: Name these objects that Swede Levov produces from his Newark factory in Philip Roth’s novel American Pastoral. The mousquetaire (“moose-kuh-TAIR”) variety of these things were traditionally worn to the opera.
Orris root, a perfume ingredient, was often kept in a container shaped like a figure from this theater tradition, whose stock characters included Pulcinella and Pierrot.
Johann Maria Farina was the first to make a perfume named for the “eau” or “water” of this German city. This city now lends its name to any type of perfume marketed towards men.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of Maya Deren’s Meshes of the Afternoon chases a hooded mirror-faced figure during one of these events. For 10 points each:
answers: dreams [or nightmares; or dream sequence; do not accept or prompt on “daydream”]
Salvador Dalí [or Salvador Domingo Felipe Jacinto Dalí i Domènech, 1st Marquess of Dalí de Púbol]
L’Age d’Or (“lahzh dor”) [or The Golden Age or Age of Gold]
parts: Name this type of event. One of these events reveals the origins of a man’s phobia in Alfred Hitchcock’s Spellbound.
This Surrealist artist designed sharply angled sets for the dream sequence in Spellbound. Luis Buñuel and this man filmed ants crawling out of a man’s hand in Un Chien Andalou.
Dalí and Buñuel also collaborated on this other film, which opens with a short documentary on scorpions.

bonuses.leadin: This poet’s antisemitism likely inspired a poem that repeats the phrase “with usura” 22 times. For 10 points each:
answers: Ezra Pound [or Ezra Weston Loomis Pound]
Elizabeth Bishop
Marianne Moore [or Marianne Craig Moore] (That poem is “Poetry.”)
parts: Name this American fascist poet of “In a Station of the Metro” who included Chinese characters in The Cantos.
This poet wrote of meeting the incarcerated Pound in her “Visit to St. Elizabeths.” The refrain “The art of losing isn’t hard to master” is found in her poem “One Art.”
Bishop’s memoir Efforts of Affection concerns this mentor of hers, who conjured “imaginary gardens with real toads in them” in a popular poem.

bonuses.leadin: These types of laws in Tudor England resulted in second-hand aristocratic clothing being donated to theater companies. For 10 points each:
answers: sumptuary laws
samurai
Benin [or Kingdom of Benin; or Republic of Benin]
parts: Identify this Latin-derived term for laws that regulate how people can dress or what types of luxury goods they can buy.

Sumptuary laws in Edo-era Japan helped preserve the prestige of these people over richer chōnin (“CHO-neen”) merchants. These aristocrats were the only ones allowed to wear two swords and followed the bushido code.

Only nobles in this West African kingdom could wear coral around their necks. The British looted this kingdom’s namesake bronzes, and it shares its name with a modern-day country whose most populous city is Cotonou (“ko-to-NOO”).

bonuses.leadin: Christiane Nüsslein-Volhard (“NOOSE-line FOAL-hart”) and Eric Wieschaus (“VEE-shouse”) were awarded the 1995 Nobel Prize for the Heidelberg Screen, a list of every one of these things that was either observable or inducible in one organism. For 10 points each:
answers: mutation
Drosophila melanogaster [or D. melanogaster; or common fruit fly; or vinegar fly; prompt on fly]
guanine [prompt on G]
parts: Identify these alterations which include transversions and transitions.
The Heidelberg Screen was carried out on these model organisms, the subject of a genome project at Berkeley. Lilian and Thomas Hunt Morgan performed research on this organism.
A common way to induce point mutations is to use ethyl methanesulfonate to alkylate this nucleobase. The protonated N1 of this compound helps cisplatin preferentially bind to it.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer these questions about river gods in Greek mythology.
answers: Troy [or Ilium]
Achelous
a fountain [or a spring]
parts: The river god Scamander who flowed near this city was so angered by Achilles choking him with all the men he was killing that he fought him three times, nearly killing Achilles. Achilles would later kill Hector, a prince of this city.

This river god transformed himself into a bull and a serpent to fight Heracles for the hand of Deianira (“DAY-uh-NEE-ruh”). According to some accounts, the horn that this god lost in that battle became the cornucopia.

The river god Alpheus relentlessly pursued Arethusa (“air-uh-THOO-zuh”), who transformed into one of these objects. Shortly after his birth, Pegasus created one of these objects called the Hippocrene.

bonuses.leadin: Archibald Primrose sought to reform this body, whose members “have done you the favor of being born.” For 10 points each:
answers: House of Lords [or House of Peers; or the Right Honourable the Lords Spiritual and Temporal of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in Parliament assembled]
The People’s Budget [prompt on the 1909 and 1910 UK budget]
Marquess of Salisbury [or Lord Salisbury; or Viscount Cranborne; or Earl of Salisbury]
parts: Name this upper house in the British Parliament whose power was restricted by the Parliament Act of 1911.
In 1909, the House of Lords rejected a budget of this name that included proposals to “wage implacable warfare against poverty” by Chancellor of the Exchequer David Lloyd George.

In 1945, a holder of this title, Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, agreed to the custom that the House of Lords wouldn’t delay most legislation. An earlier holder of this title thrice served as Conservative Prime Minister in the late 19th century and presided over the Second Boer War.
